2017-09-01.abstract: The New Kings Democrats, formed in 2008, continue to lobby for reform with the Democratic Party and to engage more of the community.
2017-09-01.snippet: The New Kings Democrats, formed in 2008, continue to lobby for reform with the Democratic Party and to engage more of the community.
2017-09-01.lead_paragraph: When their excitement of watching Barack Obama win the presidency began to fade and the reality of the local political machine — something they wanted to be a part of — had set in, Rachel Lauter and Matt Cowherd founded New Kings Democrats, the Brooklyn-based, grass-roots political organization.
2017-09-01.headline_main: In Brooklyn, Challenging the Party Establishment

2017-09-01.abstract: Fuel prices are up sharply nationwide in Hurricane Harvey’s aftermath, and may be so for months, given the blows to refining, production and shipping.
2017-09-01.snippet: Fuel prices are up sharply nationwide in Hurricane Harvey’s aftermath, and may be so for months, given the blows to refining, production and shipping.
2017-09-01.lead_paragraph: HOUSTON — Ports along the Gulf of Mexico are closed to fuel barges. Part of the biggest pipeline between Texas and New York has stopped flowing. Refineries and gas stations are flooded. Drilling rigs in the biggest shale field in Texas are running low on diesel supplies.
2017-09-01.headline_main: Storm’s Impact on Oil Industry Is Felt at Gasoline Pumps

2017-09-01.abstract: The powerful storm that struck Texas created opportunities in the eyes of some border crossers, but many fearing new immigration policies stayed put.
2017-09-01.snippet: The powerful storm that struck Texas created opportunities in the eyes of some border crossers, but many fearing new immigration policies stayed put.
2017-09-01.lead_paragraph: NUEVO LAREDO, Mexico — When a group of migrants staying in a shelter in this border city heard last weekend that Hurricane Harvey was barreling down on Texas, they did not wait. They saw an opportunity to ford the Rio Grande and slip into the United States, using the storm as cover.
2017-09-01.headline_main: South of the Border, Migrants Eye a Storm-Torn Texas

2017-09-01.abstract: Asked if he had considered resigning over policy differences with the president, Defense Secretary Jim Mattis said he was committed to serving as secretary of defense.
2017-09-01.snippet: Asked if he had considered resigning over policy differences with the president, Defense Secretary Jim Mattis said he was committed to serving as secretary of defense.
2017-09-01.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Defense Secretary Jim Mattis insisted on Thursday that he was not at odds with President Trump over North Korea and asserted that the media had misinterpreted his recent remarks on how to deal with Pyongyang.
2017-09-01.headline_main: Mattis Insists He and Trump Are on the Same Page on North Korea

2017-09-01.abstract: Even with the Islamic State on the run, U.S. advisers grapple with political and military problems in wresting Iraqi and Syrian towns from extremists.
2017-09-01.snippet: Even with the Islamic State on the run, U.S. advisers grapple with political and military problems in wresting Iraqi and Syrian towns from extremists.
2017-09-01.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Islamic State fighters are expected to make their last stand in a series of Euphrates River Valley towns and villages that American-backed Syrian and Iraqi forces are not expected to attack for months, American officials said Thursday.
2017-09-01.headline_main: Officials Eye Euphrates River Valley as Last Stand for ISIS

2017-09-01.abstract: The creator of the Brooklyn-based Caribbean culture hub likes to garden, buy Caribbean produce and check out neighbors’ West Indian Day Parade costumes.
2017-09-01.snippet: The creator of the Brooklyn-based Caribbean culture hub likes to garden, buy Caribbean produce and check out neighbors’ West Indian Day Parade costumes.
2017-09-01.lead_paragraph: Growing up in Flatbush, Brooklyn, Shelley Vidia Worrell saw her Caribbean roots reflected everywhere. So as an adult, in an effort to celebrate and preserve them, she created CaribBeing, which hosts film series and art exhibitions, and which just completed a monthlong residency in a shipping container at the Brooklyn Museum. When not at the museum or working with the mayor’s office to designate an official Little Caribbean in Flatbush, Ms. Worrell, 40, has been checking out her neighbors’ preparations for the West Indian American Day Parade, which will be held on Sept. 4 in Crown Heights. She lives in a brownstone with her husband, Janluk Stanislas, a filmmaker.
2017-09-01.headline_main: How Shelley Worrell, Creator of CaribBeing, Spends Her Sundays

2017-09-01.abstract: Quotation of the Day for Friday, September 1, 2017.
2017-09-01.snippet: Quotation of the Day for Friday, September 1, 2017.
2017-09-01.lead_paragraph: “There’s no need to test it. It’s contaminated. There’s millions of contaminants.”
2017-09-01.headline_main: Quotation of the Day: Metropolis Awash in Stagnant Brew of Chemicals, Sewage and Garbage

2017-09-01.abstract: After a contentious N.B.A. career, the basketball standout from Brooklyn became a star in China; he spoke to students Wednesday about his odyssey.
2017-09-01.snippet: After a contentious N.B.A. career, the basketball standout from Brooklyn became a star in China; he spoke to students Wednesday about his odyssey.
2017-09-01.lead_paragraph: Stephon Marbury walked into a secluded courtyard off East 12th Street in Lower Manhattan Wednesday afternoon and settled into a chair between two tables stacked with boxes of shoes.
2017-09-01.headline_main: Stephon Marbury Stops at N.Y.U., as His Story Continues

2017-09-01.abstract: Five years after the storm that wreaked havoc in New York, some victims are still rebuilding their homes. What can Houston learn from the city’s mistakes?
2017-09-01.snippet: Five years after the storm that wreaked havoc in New York, some victims are still rebuilding their homes. What can Houston learn from the city’s mistakes?
2017-09-01.lead_paragraph: Disasters are meant to inform each other, the mistakes of one recovery observed and presumably avoided in the next. Those tasked with remaking Houston in the wake of the current devastation, will have a thick playbook of error on which to reflect.
2017-09-01.headline_main: What Sandy Can Teach Harvey About Recovery

2017-09-01.abstract: A photographer captured the rush of “Race Your Own Ride” night at Raceway Park in New Jersey.
2017-09-01.snippet: A photographer captured the rush of “Race Your Own Ride” night at Raceway Park in New Jersey.
2017-09-01.lead_paragraph: You really think a Prius can blow the doors off a Hyundai Elantra? On Wednesday nights, the place to settle such a question is Englishtown, N.J., where $20 can buy drivers three runs on the quarter-mile drag strip at Raceway Park.
2017-09-01.headline_main: Drag Racing for Any Car: 12 Seconds of Pure Adrenaline

2017-09-01.abstract: A conversation with Choe Sang-Hun, the New York Times’s Seoul correspondent, about where the standoff might be headed.
2017-09-01.snippet: A conversation with Choe Sang-Hun, the New York Times’s Seoul correspondent, about where the standoff might be headed.
2017-09-01.lead_paragraph: SYDNEY, Australia — North Korea fired a ballistic missile over northern Japan this week, prompting the government in Tokyo to warn residents in its path to take cover, and leading to another round of questions about whether war will soon strike the Korean Peninsula.
2017-09-01.headline_main: What North Korea’s Missile Tests Look Like to a South Korean Reporter

2017-09-01.abstract: This week’s Australia newsletter features a conversation with our correspondent in Seoul, South Korea.
2017-09-01.snippet: This week’s Australia newsletter features a conversation with our correspondent in Seoul, South Korea.
2017-09-01.lead_paragraph: Damien Cave, our Australia bureau chief, shares insights on global news, local recommendations and feedback from readers in this weekly newsletter. To receive it in your inbox, sign up here.
2017-09-01.headline_main: Discussing North Korea

2017-09-01.abstract: Something appears to be amiss with Federer’s game, casting some doubt on his status as a favorite at the U.S. Open.
2017-09-01.snippet: Something appears to be amiss with Federer’s game, casting some doubt on his status as a favorite at the U.S. Open.
2017-09-01.lead_paragraph: The signs were there before the United States Open began, even if many devoted fans refused to recognize them. Roger Federer had injured his 36-year-old back during a tournament in Montreal two weeks ago, then had withdrawn from the next tournament in Cincinnati to rest it.
2017-09-01.headline_main: Though Federer Survives 2nd 5-Set Match, His Play Invites Questions

2017-09-01.abstract: A federal judge ruled that opponents of the law, which would restrict the most common type of second-trimester abortion, were likely to succeed in court.
2017-09-01.snippet: A federal judge ruled that opponents of the law, which would restrict the most common type of second-trimester abortion, were likely to succeed in court.
2017-09-01.lead_paragraph: A federal judge has temporarily blocked a Texas law that would restrict the most common type of second-trimester abortion.
2017-09-01.headline_main: Texas Abortion Restriction Is Temporarily Blocked

2017-09-01.abstract: The Boston executive Dombrowski has won just one World Series in his 40-year career, with the Marlins. But that’s never stopped him from pursuing more.
2017-09-01.snippet: The Boston executive Dombrowski has won just one World Series in his 40-year career, with the Marlins. But that’s never stopped him from pursuing more.
2017-09-01.lead_paragraph: The doors are now locked to all newcomers hoping to play past Oct. 1. Once September arrives, baseball executives cannot add pieces to help in the postseason. Everyone eligible for a playoff roster must be in his organization before Sept. 1. The gang’s all there now, for some lucky franchise. We just don’t know which.
2017-09-01.headline_main: Dave Dombrowski, Ever the Tinkerer, Readies the Red Sox for October

2017-09-01.abstract: The underfunded program encourages development in flood-prone areas.
2017-09-01.snippet: The underfunded program encourages development in flood-prone areas.
2017-09-01.lead_paragraph: It was clear long before Hurricane Harvey slammed into Texas that the National Flood Insurance Program, the government’s most important means of recovering from such disasters, needed to be overhauled. It fails to account for the full extent of flood risk, encourages development in areas known to be flood-prone and is not realistically funded.
2017-09-01.headline_main: How Federal Flood Insurance Puts Homes at Risk

2017-09-01.abstract: A Patrick Berry Friday is a very good Friday indeed.
2017-09-01.snippet: A Patrick Berry Friday is a very good Friday indeed.
2017-09-01.lead_paragraph: FRIDAY PUZZLE — Don’t tell anyone, but this is a rough week for me. I took The Boy to college for his first semester, and I’m incredibly proud of how much he’s grown up in the past few years. I love the young man he’s become. He’s outgrown whatever teenage quirks he had, and he’s really nice to be around. And now he’s leaving. By the way, today’s puzzle is a really nice one by Patrick Berry.
2017-09-01.headline_main: Without Wasting a Word

2017-09-01.abstract: From “Modern Times” to “Office Space,” here are a few movies about work to sample this weekend.
2017-09-01.snippet: From “Modern Times” to “Office Space,” here are a few movies about work to sample this weekend.
2017-09-01.lead_paragraph: If you’re lucky enough to have time off this Labor Day weekend, put in a few extra hours with a movie or two about the workplace. Whether they are set in cube farms or factories, the stories of workers’ struggles and triumphs will always have a place in the movies. Here are 7 to start with. Get to work.
2017-09-01.headline_main: 7 Movies to Watch This Labor Day Weekend

2017-09-01.abstract: The men, including two journalists for The Daily Mail chronicling a rescue attempt, jumped out of a boat shortly before it crashed into power lines.
2017-09-01.snippet: The men, including two journalists for The Daily Mail chronicling a rescue attempt, jumped out of a boat shortly before it crashed into power lines.
2017-09-01.lead_paragraph: Clinging to a tree branch in torrential rain and howling winds, Ruaridh Connellan fought against the ferocious current of Houston’s Greens Bayou. His body was weak and under water. Are we going to die, he said over and over again to a colleague hugging the trunk of the tree.
2017-09-01.headline_main: For 18 Hours, 3 Men in Houston Fought for Survival in Hurricane Harvey

2017-09-01.abstract: It was widely reportedly that P.S.G. will pay 180 million euros ($216 million) for the 18-year-old Monaco forward.
2017-09-01.snippet: It was widely reportedly that P.S.G. will pay 180 million euros ($216 million) for the 18-year-old Monaco forward.
2017-09-01.lead_paragraph: Forward Kylian Mbappe’s expected move to Paris St.-Germain finally went through Thursday evening, as Monaco loaned him until the end of the season along with an option to make the move permanent. No financial details were given by P.S.G. in its statement, but the permanent deal would be from 2018 to 2022.
2017-09-01.headline_main: Soccer Star Kylian Mbappe’s Move to Paris St.-Germain Is Completed

2017-09-01.snippet: A Jamaican woman chafes at the reality that expressing affection for her wife can lead to confrontations with her fellow immigrants in New York.
2017-09-01.lead_paragraph: On our first date, I dared to give her a lingering hug on a crowded subway platform on West Fourth Street, an unusual display of physical affection on my part, which I blamed on the wine. It was the start of spring, the city in bloom.
2017-09-01.headline_main: Who’s Allowed to Hold Hands?

2017-09-01.snippet: Bird, after a miserable start and an ankle injury, homered for the second game in a row as the Yankees survived the ninth to thump the Red Sox.

2017-09-01.headline_main: With Aaron Judge Struggling at the Plate, Greg Bird Steps Up for the Yankees

2017-09-01.abstract: The victims were trying to escape renewed violence in western Myanmar, where the predominantly Muslim group faces oppression.
2017-09-01.snippet: The victims were trying to escape renewed violence in western Myanmar, where the predominantly Muslim group faces oppression.
2017-09-01.lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — At least 46 people believed to be Rohingya fleeing violence in western Myanmar have been found dead on the banks of a river along the boundary with Bangladesh, Bangladeshi officials said on Friday.
2017-09-01.headline_main: Boats Carrying Rohingya Fleeing Myanmar Sink, Killing 46

2017-09-01.abstract: Had America not absorbed the sheer skeeviness of that decade, we wouldn’t be where we are today.
2017-09-01.snippet: Had America not absorbed the sheer skeeviness of that decade, we wouldn’t be where we are today.
2017-09-01.lead_paragraph: It began on the slopes in Aspen the last week of 1989. A real estate mogul and his paramour, a model named Marla Maples, had the misfortune to walk straight into the path of the mogul’s wife, Ivana Trump. There was a confrontation. And a short time later the gossip columns were consumed with the first juicy scandal of the 1990s. One tabloid headline went so far as to declare “Best Sex I Ever Had,” a reference (some say apocryphal) to how Ms. Maples rated Donald Trump.
2017-09-01.headline_main: The 1990s Gave Us the Trump Teens

2017-09-01.abstract: People are no longer pouring into America’s cities. And that’s bad news for everyone.
2017-09-01.snippet: People are no longer pouring into America’s cities. And that’s bad news for everyone.
2017-09-01.lead_paragraph: TORONTO — For all the concern about the gentrification, rising housing prices and the growing gap between the rich and poor in our leading cities, an even bigger threat lies on the horizon: The urban revival that swept across America over the past decade or two may be in danger. As it turns out, the much-ballyhooed new age of the city might be giving way to a great urban stall-out.
2017-09-01.headline_main: The Urban Revival Is Over

2017-09-01.abstract: An explosion in Afghanistan left me with daily migraines. The best solution is illegal: marijuana.
2017-09-01.snippet: An explosion in Afghanistan left me with daily migraines. The best solution is illegal: marijuana.
2017-09-01.lead_paragraph: The explosion that wounded me during a Taliban ambush in Afghanistan in 2010 left me with a traumatic brain injury and post-traumatic stress. In 2012 I was medically retired from the Marine Corps because of debilitating migraines, vertigo and crippling depression. After a nine-year career, I sought care from the Department of Veterans Affairs.
2017-09-01.headline_main: Make Pot Legal for Veterans With Traumatic Brain Injury

2017-09-01.abstract: We all have many identities, and we do best when we’re able to move through them gracefully.
2017-09-01.snippet: We all have many identities, and we do best when we’re able to move through them gracefully.
2017-09-01.lead_paragraph: The Lebanese-born writer Amin Maalouf made an interesting point about identity: Other people often pick ours for us. The anti-Semite elevates the Jewish consciousness in the Jew. The Sunni radical elevates Shiite consciousness in the Shiite.
2017-09-01.headline_main: In Praise of Equipoise

2017-09-01.abstract: When normally stoic scientists start draining the barrel of awful superlatives, it’s time to pay attention.
2017-09-01.snippet: When normally stoic scientists start draining the barrel of awful superlatives, it’s time to pay attention.
2017-09-01.lead_paragraph: On Monday, most of us were still trying to fathom what nine trillion gallons of water would feel like — that hydraulic cube over downtown Houston, four miles square and two miles high. And then the cube doubled to become the most extreme rain event in American history.
2017-09-01.headline_main: The Week the Earth Stood Still

2017-09-01.abstract: A judge has temporarily blocked an attempt to force localities to cooperate with harsh federal policies, but the legal struggle will continue.
2017-09-01.snippet: A judge has temporarily blocked an attempt to force localities to cooperate with harsh federal policies, but the legal struggle will continue.
2017-09-01.lead_paragraph: Anyone watching the storm devastation in Texas had to be stirred by the mix of resilient victims and valiant rescuers — a mix of people from all backgrounds united in a struggle for survival. The heroic images of community resolve could not have been a more apt backdrop for the decision by a federal judge in Texas in midstorm to block the Republican-controlled state government’s attempt to crack down on so-called sanctuary cities and make them enforce federal immigration laws.
2017-09-01.headline_main: Blocking a Bad Immigration Law in Texas

2017-09-01.abstract: “I just feel like they try to take the weak road,” Sabathia, the Yankees’ starter, said after Eduardo Nunez bunted on Boston’s second at-bat of the night Thursday.
2017-09-01.snippet: “I just feel like they try to take the weak road,” Sabathia, the Yankees’ starter, said after Eduardo Nunez bunted on Boston’s second at-bat of the night Thursday.
2017-09-01.lead_paragraph: It was a delicately hit ball, a bunt placed by Eduardo Nunez just in front of the pitcher’s mound in the first inning on Thursday. But for C. C. Sabathia, who came down off the hill to field it, the bunt came saddled with a gesture, one that seemed bold enough to awaken a bear in winter.
2017-09-01.headline_main: Red Sox’s Gentle Bunt Draws a Furious Response From C. C. Sabathia

2017-09-01.abstract: A documentary available on Vogue’s website chronicles the rocky path of a comet of the fashion world.
2017-09-01.snippet: A documentary available on Vogue’s website chronicles the rocky path of a comet of the fashion world.
2017-09-01.lead_paragraph: Zac Posen’s mythic ascent to fashion superstardom is retold in “House of Z,” a documentary by Sandy Chronopoulos available for streaming on Wednesday, Sept. 6, at Vogue.com/houseofz. The son of an artist and a lawyer living in SoHo, Mr. Posen first draped fabric on dolls as a toddler. As a teen at Saint Ann’s School in Brooklyn, he turned the actresses Paz de la Huerta, Jemima Kirke and Lola Schnabel into muses. While a student at Central St. Martin’s in London, he designed a pink silk dress for Naomi Campbell that was passed from woman to woman before catching the eye of a reporter for The New York Times. Buyers came calling and Mr. Posen set up a studio with the help of his mother and sister. A star was born. He was 20.
2017-09-01.headline_main: In ‘House of Z,’ the Jagged Arc of Zac Posen

2017-09-01.abstract: The program features several of Roeg’s films from his time as a cinematographer, as well as his signature non-linear approach to directing.
2017-09-01.snippet: The program features several of Roeg’s films from his time as a cinematographer, as well as his signature non-linear approach to directing.
2017-09-01.lead_paragraph: The great British filmmaker Nicolas Roeg was a cinematographer before he was a director, and the partial retrospective of his work now underway at the Quad Cinema is wisely including two classic films highlighting his lens work.
2017-09-01.headline_main: Quad Cinema’s Nicolas Roeg Retrospective Highlights a Director’s Lens Work

2017-09-01.abstract: The busy summer theater season in the Berkshires is almost over, but Barrington Stage Company extended its production of “Company” through Sept. 10.
2017-09-01.snippet: The busy summer theater season in the Berkshires is almost over, but Barrington Stage Company extended its production of “Company” through Sept. 10.
2017-09-01.lead_paragraph: The official last day of summer is not until Sept. 22, but let’s face it: It’s essentially over after Labor Day, and we’re all going to gripe about how it went by faster than ever this year and we didn’t do enough.
2017-09-01.headline_main: ‘Company’ Helps Take Those Dog Days of Summer for a Walk

2017-09-01.abstract: Since 2013, this wide-ranging exploration of contemporary vocal music has had the intimate feel of witnessing works in progress.
2017-09-01.snippet: Since 2013, this wide-ranging exploration of contemporary vocal music has had the intimate feel of witnessing works in progress.
2017-09-01.lead_paragraph: The art making feels unusually personal during the Resonant Bodies Festival, which began in 2013 and has swiftly become something to look forward to each year. A wide-ranging exploration of contemporary vocal music, lately hosted at Roulette in Brooklyn, it follows a simple formula: Three nights (Tuesday through Thursday, Sept. 5-7), three singers per night, one 45-minute set per singer. The vocalists are the curators.
2017-09-01.headline_main: Resonant Bodies Festival: Witness the Process at Roulette

2017-09-01.abstract: A new exhibition illuminates Lawrence’s inspiration and his enduring influence.
2017-09-01.snippet: A new exhibition illuminates Lawrence’s inspiration and his enduring influence.
2017-09-01.lead_paragraph: Jacob Lawrence may be best known for his Great Migration series of paintings, depicting the movement northward of millions of black Americans from the South in the early 20th century. But the artist himself was born in Atlantic City, after his own parents made the journey. And this week, the SCAD Museum of Art in Savannah, Ga., will mark Lawrence’s 100th birthday on Thursday, Sept. 7, with the opening of “Lines of Influence,” an exhibition that traces both the sources of his inspiration and his enduring resonance with contemporary artists.
2017-09-01.headline_main: A Century of Jacob Lawrence

2017-09-01.abstract: Ms. Pirici, who lives and works in Bucharest and Berlin, will create a moving barrier of performers at the top of Manhattan’s verdant pedestrian highway.
2017-09-01.snippet: Ms. Pirici, who lives and works in Bucharest and Berlin, will create a moving barrier of performers at the top of Manhattan’s verdant pedestrian highway.
2017-09-01.lead_paragraph: Anyone strolling the High Line between Tuesday, Sept. 5, and Thursday may encounter traffic in the Rail Yards, the park’s northernmost section. At 30th Street between 11th and 12th Avenues, performers will create a moving barrier for pedestrians to pass through. The event, from 4 to 7 p.m., is Alexandra Pirici’s “Threshold,” a work that the artist describes not as a performance but as an “ongoing action.”
2017-09-01.headline_main: Alexandra Pirici Installs a ‘Threshold’ at the High Line

2017-09-01.snippet: In which we consult the Book Review’s past to shed light on the books of the present. This week: Nora Ephron on the advantages of revision.
2017-09-01.lead_paragraph: This week Lisa Schwarzbaum reviews a new book about Nora Ephron and her romantic comedies. Ephron was a regular contributor to the Book Review, and in this essay from 1986, she ruminates on the unexpected advantages of revision. Below is an excerpt.

2017-09-01.abstract: Give it at least an hour. Strike a balance between poesy and mundane description.
2017-09-01.snippet: Give it at least an hour. Strike a balance between poesy and mundane description.
2017-09-01.lead_paragraph: ‘‘You need a minimum of one hour,’’ says Sonia Cancian, an assistant professor of history at Zayed University in Dubai. Find a quiet place away from distractions and spend time just thinking about what you want to communicate. ‘‘A letter has a remarkable way of transpiring feelings, emotions, honesty, sincerity and authenticity,’’ says Cancian, who insists on the singular power of a love letter even in the era of more immediate communication methods like video chat or texting.
2017-09-01.headline_main: How to Write a Love Letter

2017-09-01.abstract: Can a spouse with an interesting childhood be compelled to turn it into a book?
2017-09-01.snippet: Can a spouse with an interesting childhood be compelled to turn it into a book?
2017-09-01.lead_paragraph: Nicholas writes: My wife had an insane childhood. Her father made her sneak into other people’s gardens to steal orchids so he could sell them. A family friend would come and go, with tales of faking Scud missile launches in Iraq. Not to mention long-ago connections with the Crowninshields, the money long run out. She doesn’t want to embarrass her relatives. But I think she should write a book.
2017-09-01.headline_main: Judge John Hodgman on Coercing Your Wife Into Writing a Memoir

2017-09-01.abstract: For this issue, the new business in Washington of selling a Trump bump.
2017-09-01.snippet: For this issue, the new business in Washington of selling a Trump bump.
2017-09-01.lead_paragraph: Gail Bichler, design director: “This week’s cover story is about a new cast of characters in Washington who are using their relationships to Donald Trump’s 2016 campaign as a ticket into the capital’s clubby influence industry. To underscore their outsider status —and their sometimes unorthodox methods — we hit on the idea of a D.I.Y. flier.”

2017-09-01.abstract: Is aging a form of surrender to fate?

2017-09-01.abstract: Julian Lucas considers how family stories go beyond genealogy to discover those “who became ‘our’ ancestors” and those who didn’t.
2017-09-01.snippet: Julian Lucas considers how family stories go beyond genealogy to discover those “who became ‘our’ ancestors” and those who didn’t.
2017-09-01.lead_paragraph: Family sagas write history through microcosm, tracing a clan’s rise, survival and, more often than not, ultimate dissolution. Thomas Mann’s healthy bourgeois Buddenbrooks succumb to decadent sterility; Gabriel García Márquez’s Buendías are erased by a hurricane; the Starks of Winterfell are massacred in the Riverlands. A family is sacrificed to time, and in their entrails readers find auguries of larger motions. The critic Frank Kermode believed that novels developed alongside a loss of faith in biblical chronology, as substitutes for Adam and Eve’s universal family plot. He is borne out by recent years’ fruitful crop of epics rooted in the familiar soil of fathers and daughters, mothers and sons, blood, sex, bastardy and inheritance.
2017-09-01.headline_main: Epic Stories That Expand the Universal Family Plot

2017-09-01.headline_main: Suspense Fiction That Mines the Terrain of Female Guilt

2017-09-01.abstract: Sicily, Lake Como and the Amalfi Coast are among the destinations where hotel packages are available (some include airfare).
2017-09-01.snippet: Sicily, Lake Como and the Amalfi Coast are among the destinations where hotel packages are available (some include airfare).
2017-09-01.lead_paragraph: Italy is always in style as a vacation destination for travelers from the United States, and this year is no exception. The country is a best-seller within the travel networks Virtuoso and Signature Travel Network, the latter of which has a double-digit growth in sales in 2017 for Italy trips. Flight searches are also up, but, fortunately, airfare prices are down: between May 1 and July 10, Cheapflights.com saw flight searches to Milan and Rome from the United States for travel for this September and October increase 43 percent, compared with the same period last year while ticket prices dropped by 18 percent to Milan and by 17 percent to Rome. Misty Ewing, the global head of public relations for Virtuoso, encourages value-seekers to consider a fall Italian getaway. “Prices drop significantly, but the weather is still beautiful,” she said.
2017-09-01.headline_main: Fall in Italy: Lovely Weather, Lower Prices

2017-09-01.abstract: This week’s crime novels delve into the Spanish past and into film history, then grapple with two present-day children tormented by dangerous visions.
2017-09-01.snippet: This week’s crime novels delve into the Spanish past and into film history, then grapple with two present-day children tormented by dangerous visions.
2017-09-01.lead_paragraph: Louise Penny wrote the book on escapist mysteries — a dozen of them, in fact, almost all set in the sheltered Canadian village of Three Pines. “It was a haven, a buffer, from the cares and cruelty of the world,” she tells us in GLASS HOUSES (Minotaur, $28.99), a place seemingly so free of malice and discord that Armand Gamache, chief superintendent of the Sûreté du Québec, and his wife, Reine-Marie, have made it their sanctuary. One of the pleasures of returning to this series is visiting old friends in the village like Gabri and Olivier, who run the convivial B&B; the artist Clara Morrow, whose startling portraits will haunt you; and (a personal favorite) Ruth Zardo, a poet who accurately describes herself as “a crazy old woman who prays for Satan and has a duck.”
2017-09-01.headline_main: Mythic Revenge, a Mythic Film and Possibly Mythic Memories

2017-09-01.abstract: “Y is for Yesterday,” the penultimate installment of Sue Grafton’s Alphabet Series, premieres on the Best-Seller list at No. 1.
2017-09-01.snippet: “Y is for Yesterday,” the penultimate installment of Sue Grafton’s Alphabet Series, premieres on the Best-Seller list at No. 1.
2017-09-01.lead_paragraph: THE ABCS OF MYSTERY: Back in 1982, when Sue Grafton wrote the first novel in what was to become her career-making Alphabet series, she knew she was taking a risk. “It was a crapshoot,” she told NPR’s Dwayne Brown. “I wasn’t even sure I could sell ‘A Is for Alibi.’” But she wanted to get back into solo writing after a career in Hollywood, and detective fiction called. The risk paid off: The Alphabet books, which star the Southern California-based private investigator Kinsey Millhone, have been steadily enthralling readers with heists, betrayals and murders for the last 35 years.
2017-09-01.headline_main: A Decades-old Detective Series Is Still on Top

2017-09-01.abstract: Mr. Nelson headlines the Outlaw Music Festival; Mr. Erickson hits Brooklyn and Jersey City; and Mr. Clapton brings some Austin six-stringers to the Garden.
2017-09-01.snippet: Mr. Nelson headlines the Outlaw Music Festival; Mr. Erickson hits Brooklyn and Jersey City; and Mr. Clapton brings some Austin six-stringers to the Garden.
2017-09-01.lead_paragraph: With all eyes on a hurricane-torn Texas, its perpetually touring musicians carry a spirit of resilience. Willie Nelson, despite recent respiratory problems, has been barnstorming across America with his encompassing repertoire of Americana. This weekend he headlines the Outlaw Music Festival of roots-rock and country in amphitheaters: Friday, Sept. 8, at PNC Bank Arts Center in Holmdel, N.J., and Saturday at Jones Beach Theater in Wantagh, N.Y. The lineup includes his son’s band, Lukas Nelson and Promise of the Real, along with Sheryl Crow, the Avett Brothers and Margo Price. The paladin of Texas psychedelia, Roky Erickson — who led the 13th Floor Elevators in the 1960s and returned, after some difficult years personally, with garage-rock visions of aliens, demons and redemption — performs in Brooklyn on Wednesday and Thursday at Rough Trade and Jersey City on Friday at White Eagle Hall. Meanwhile, Eric Clapton is bringing Austin bluesmen as openers — and rivals — when he plays Madison Square Garden on Thursday and Friday, sharing the bill with the incendiary guitarist Gary Clark Jr. and with Jimmie Vaughan, a founder of the Fabulous Thunderbirds.
2017-09-01.headline_main: Willie Nelson, Roky Erickson, Eric Clapton: Twang, Psychedelia and Blues

2017-09-01.lead_paragraph: Fire engulfed part of a chemical plant northeast of Houston on Friday evening, sending thick black smoke high into the sky, a statement from Arkema, the owner of the plant, confirmed. It was the same facility where, on Thursday, a chemical storage trailer exploded, setting off a fire. Flooding from Harvey, once a Category 4 hurricane that hit southeast Texas last week, had knocked out the refrigeration system needed to keep the chemicals stable.

2017-09-01.abstract: A photographer finds beauty in the margins of action and light at the United States Open.
2017-09-01.snippet: A photographer finds beauty in the margins of action and light at the United States Open.
2017-09-01.lead_paragraph: I am always attracted to the edges because they define shape and give context. And I always seek a spark of photographic magic on the edges of light and shadow. So when I was tasked to cover the opening days of the United States Open this year, I found myself looking to the margins of both the action and the light as the world’s premier players performed an exquisitely elegant dance of athleticism and grace with the assistance of an army of support: ball boys and ball girls, line judges and members of the security staff, working in view of a sea of awe-inspired fans, myself included. I worked the courtside edges, from Arthur Ashe Stadium to the practice courts, to incorporate some of those people into photographs that usually strive to be free of distractions, and I allowed myself the pleasure of finding beauty as the players tried to gain their own edge.
2017-09-01.headline_main: Capturing Action Just Off the Court at the U.S. Open

2017-09-01.lead_paragraph: By the end of the season, most of the College Football Playoff contenders’ 12 or 13 games will seem, in retrospect, like insignificant and anonymous blowouts of weaker opposition. 2017-09-01.abstract: For the choreographer of “Come From Away” and “Escape to Margaritaville,” designing a home requires as much care as putting on a Broadway show.
2017-09-01.snippet: For the choreographer of “Come From Away” and “Escape to Margaritaville,” designing a home requires as much care as putting on a Broadway show.
2017-09-01.lead_paragraph: The choreographer Kelly Devine grew up in Los Angeles, and stuck around for the first two decades of her career to stage dances for film, television, videos and commercials. She moved east a dozen years ago to focus on Broadway musicals, and has since worked on “Rock of Ages,” “Rocky,” “Doctor Zhivago” and “Come From Away,” in the process picking up two Tony Award nominations. Next up: “Escape to Margaritaville.”

2017-09-01.lead_paragraph: Tuberculosis kills almost two million people a year. A perfect vaccine could save many of them, but the one now in use — invented in the 1920s and known as BCG, for Bacillus Calmette-Guérin — has so many flaws that some countries, including the United States, have never adopted it.
2017-09-01.headline_main: Lasting Merit Found in a Tuberculosis Vaccine Invented a Century Ago

2017-09-01.abstract: Kanopy, a movie-streaming service that is free for New York Public Library members, is a garden of cinematic delights. Here’s how to use it.
2017-09-01.snippet: Kanopy, a movie-streaming service that is free for New York Public Library members, is a garden of cinematic delights. Here’s how to use it.
2017-09-01.lead_paragraph: A few years ago, back when video rental stores were still around but clearly an endangered species (Tower Records had shut down, Blockbuster was in trouble and Netflix was still dealing in DVDs), I was chatting with a friend, a fellow cinephile experiencing an economic downturn. (As it happened, he had worked for Tower.) It was difficult to keep up with classic releases on home video, particularly stuff from the Criterion Collection, he said, but fortunately for him titles would eventually turn up at his local public library. And he didn’t have to wait long for them either, since few people in his New Jersey town (which had once been mine) were keen on art or foreign films.
2017-09-01.headline_main: Library Cards Unlock Film Vaults

2017-09-01.headline_main: A Life’s Many Acts Culminate in the Kitchen at NA/NA in Paris

2017-09-01.abstract: The restoration of Chartres Cathedral asks questions about how we preserve the past — and which past we preserve.
2017-09-01.snippet: The restoration of Chartres Cathedral asks questions about how we preserve the past — and which past we preserve.
2017-09-01.lead_paragraph: CHARTRES, France — The pilgrim did not find what he was searching for. As a child, Patrice Bertrand heard his mother recount details of her visit to the shrine of the famous Black Madonna of Chartres Cathedral, 60 miles southwest of Paris. Now Mr. Bertrand, 41, of Nantes, was following in her footsteps. But he was perplexed by what he discovered: “The statue I came to see is not here anymore,” he said. The Black Madonna had become white.
2017-09-01.headline_main: A Controversial Restoration That Wipes Away the Past

2017-09-01.lead_paragraph: There’s no way around reviewing “Tulip Fever” without noting that the movie has been buried deeper than a tulip bulb. The Vulture writer Kyle Buchanan has already provided a rundown of the substantial delays in the film’s release, which — for a project once regarded as an Oscar contender — might be taken as a sign of an odor other than floral. This week, Harvey Weinstein, the co-chairman of the Weinstein Company, the film’s distributor, took the extraordinary step of defending the movie in advance with a column for Deadline Hollywood, though it is laced with passive-aggressive barbs like “I know this film’s not perfect, very few are, but it’s a perfectly good time in a movie theater.”
2017-09-01.headline_main: Review: ‘Tulip Fever’ Delivers a Wilted Period Piece

2017-09-01.lead_paragraph: Tuesday was my first day back at school at Baruch College for my senior year. I had been looking forward to starting class again, but it was impossible to pay attention. I was completely distracted by the whiplash of news about whether Donald Trump would end the executive order Deferred Action for Childhood Arrivals, or DACA, — the policy President Barack Obama announced in 2012 that allowed almost 800,000 immigrant youths like me to step out of the shadows of society.

2017-09-01.abstract: It’s a big city, with plenty to do, see, hear and watch. Here’s a sampling of cultural highlights this weekend and over the week ahead.
2017-09-01.snippet: It’s a big city, with plenty to do, see, hear and watch. Here’s a sampling of cultural highlights this weekend and over the week ahead.
2017-09-01.lead_paragraph: The latest side project from the popular American Ballet Theater principal dancer Daniil Simkin involves real-time motion sensors; costumes by Dior; and projections by his father, Dmitrij, also an accomplished ballet dancer. A commission by the Works & Process Rotunda Project, this 30-minute work — scheduled to be performed twice nightly, at 8 and 9:30 p.m., on Monday and Tuesday — features Mr. Simkin, the Ballet Theater soloist Cassandra Trenary, the Hubbard Street dancer Ana Lopez and Brett Conway in juicy choreography by the Hubbard Street house choreographer, Alejandro Cerrudo. With observers watching from above, standing along the Guggenheim’s spiraling ramps, the dancers will tangle with each other and their own shadows, which, thanks to technology, will seem to have developed minds of their own. BRIAN SCHAEFER
2017-09-01.headline_main: 10 Things to Do in NYC Now

2017-09-01.abstract: Abdullah el-Faisal’s teaching has influenced many terrorists. Now he’s charged in the first international terror case brought by New York prosecutors.
2017-09-01.snippet: Abdullah el-Faisal’s teaching has influenced many terrorists. Now he’s charged in the first international terror case brought by New York prosecutors.
2017-09-01.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — For two decades, Abdullah el-Faisal has preached jihad, on the streets and online, first promoting the grim theology of Al Qaeda and then endorsing the Islamic State. Imprisoned in England and later deported from Kenya to his native Jamaica, he has in recent years kept up his internet proselytizing from his home near Kingston. His influence has turned up repeatedly in major terrorism cases.
2017-09-01.headline_main: A Long-Pursued ISIS Preacher Is Finally Charged in New York

2017-09-02.lead_paragraph: THE Summer of Love began with a burst of flower power. On June 1, 1967, the Beatles released “Sgt. Pepper’s Lonely Hearts Club Band,” and the horticulture was nearly as impressive as the music. In the foreground of the album cover, the flowers spelled out the band’s name, and formed other shapes nearby — a guitar here, a star there. A daisy grew from John’s shoulder, a natural epaulet.

2017-09-02.snippet: The president has had a rocky few months. Now comes his first true test: reforming labor rules.
2017-09-02.lead_paragraph: Since his spectacular victory in France’s presidential race in May on a promise of a new kind of politics, Emmanuel Macron has had a rocky ride. The military chief of staff quit in anger over budget cuts; the president endured ridicule over how much he spent on his makeup; he has been accused of being aloof; his popularity ratings have plummeted. All that, however, is just a prelude to the real battle.
2017-09-02.headline_main: The Real Battle Begins: Mr. Macron vs. the Labor Code

2017-09-02.snippet: Were the 1990s a peak never to be seen again?
2017-09-02.lead_paragraph: The working woman was everywhere in 1980s and 1990s pop culture: The tough single gal Murphy Brown ran the news on TV every week. Dolly Parton in “9 to 5,” Melanie Griffith in “Working Girl,” and the ominously coldhearted mother in “Mrs. Doubtfire.”
2017-09-02.headline_main: The Best Era for Working Women Was 20 Years Ago

2017-09-02.abstract: No safe space or trigger warning lifts the sting of a cold new world.
2017-09-02.snippet: No safe space or trigger warning lifts the sting of a cold new world.
2017-09-02.lead_paragraph: Across the country, college freshmen are settling into their new lives and grappling with something that doesn’t compete with protests and political correctness for the media’s attention, something that no one prepared them for, something that has nothing to do with being “snowflakes” and everything to do with being human.
2017-09-02.headline_main: The Real Campus Scourge

2017-09-02.abstract: Mr. Trump says that all Americans will win big from tax cuts on businesses and the wealthy. It’s a tough sell because it’s not true.
2017-09-02.snippet: Mr. Trump says that all Americans will win big from tax cuts on businesses and the wealthy. It’s a tough sell because it’s not true.
2017-09-02.lead_paragraph: As they return to Washington this week from their August recess, House Republicans on the Ways and Means Committee have their work cut out for them. Their job is to draft a major tax-cut bill for Congress to pass, ideally by year-end, to avoid closing out 2017 without a single big legislative win. The policy objective is to steeply cut tax rates for businesses and wealthy individuals. The political aim, and the point of President Trump’s speech last Wednesday, is to persuade the men and women in the Trump working-class base that a tax cut for the wealthy would be good for them, too.
2017-09-02.headline_main: The False Promises in President Trump’s Tax Plan

2017-09-02.abstract: Discipline can be a lose-lose proposition. Here’s a different method.
2017-09-02.snippet: Discipline can be a lose-lose proposition. Here’s a different method.
2017-09-02.lead_paragraph: To his teachers at Ridgeway High School in Memphis, Jason Okonofua was a handful. During class, his mind drifted and he would lose the thread of the lesson. He slouched at his desk and dozed off.
2017-09-02.headline_main: Don’t Suspend Students. Empathize.

2017-09-02.abstract: Stiletto heels won’t help, but she could bring some grace to the chaos.
2017-09-02.snippet: Stiletto heels won’t help, but she could bring some grace to the chaos.
2017-09-02.lead_paragraph: We are not going to dwell on Melania Trump’s flying to flood-ravaged Texas in stilettos, or sneakers, here. But nature abhors a vacuum, and the first lady’s fans and critics focus on her costumes in part because, so far, that’s about all they see of Melania Trump. In the back-to-work spirit of Labor Day, let’s reflect on Mrs. Trump’s plans as first lady now that she’s settled in the White House and Barron, her only child, heads back to school.
2017-09-02.headline_main: Can Melania Trump Rise Above It All?

2017-09-02.lead_paragraph: NAIROBI, Kenya — The chief justice of Kenya’s Supreme Court, David Maraga, is a Seventh-day Adventist who refuses to preside over a court case on a Saturday. Once accused of corruption, he went on live television and swore on the Bible that he had never taken a bribe.
2017-09-02.headline_main: Kenyans Celebrate Court’s Ruling to Nullify Election

2017-09-02.abstract: An anti-government stance made Hurricane Harvey’s impact worse. Can big government now make things better?
2017-09-02.snippet: An anti-government stance made Hurricane Harvey’s impact worse. Can big government now make things better?
2017-09-02.lead_paragraph: HOUSTON — I am sure that by now many of you have seen the heartening pictures of the countless volunteers here in Houston, lining up to help out in the wake of Hurricane Harvey, kayaking to the rescue, opening their homes to strangers, feeding the hungry from their own kitchens. The scenes are even more moving in person, when you see the pickup trucks piled high with plastic bags of donations causing traffic jams around the George R. Brown Convention Center, and still more people coming in on foot, bearing boxes of diapers, dog food, bar soap, pillows, blankets and virtually anything else a human in an emergency could use.
2017-09-02.headline_main: Houston Needs a Hand

2017-09-02.abstract: Sometimes what you’re looking for has been right there all along, shouting over women on cable news shows.
2017-09-02.snippet: Sometimes what you’re looking for has been right there all along, shouting over women on cable news shows.
2017-09-02.lead_paragraph: I am a peaceable person. By that I mean I avoid conflict and also I’m quite lazy. People generally appeal to me. I can see their good side. I sometimes have fleeting antagonisms: toward a waitress I feel is being too performative in her friendship with a coffee shop regular, or that woman on the subway eating a plum really loudly. But in general, I have a smiley face and at the risk of sounding bonkers, I make friends with almost everyone I come across. What I’m missing, I’ve come to realize after a summer of cookouts and heart-to-hearts and hiking trips, is an enemy.
2017-09-02.headline_main: Stephen Miller Is the Enemy of My Dreams

2017-09-02.abstract: Michael Barbaro interviewed Roger Stone, one of President Trump’s oldest advisers. Maggie Haberman joins Mr. Barbaro for an analysis of the conversation.
2017-09-02.snippet: Michael Barbaro interviewed Roger Stone, one of President Trump’s oldest advisers. Maggie Haberman joins Mr. Barbaro for an analysis of the conversation.
2017-09-02.lead_paragraph: Note from January 25, 2019: Roger Stone was arrested by the F.B.I. on Friday in connection to the special counsel’s investigation and was charged with seven counts, including obstruction of an official proceeding, making false statements and witness tampering. Read the latest here.
2017-09-02.headline_main: ‘The New Washington’: Roger Stone

2017-09-02.abstract: The popularity of shared-use bikes has brought a wave of misbehavior, raising questions about social decay and the decline of decorum.
2017-09-02.snippet: The popularity of shared-use bikes has brought a wave of misbehavior, raising questions about social decay and the decline of decorum.
2017-09-02.lead_paragraph: BEIJING — Liu Lijing, a mechanic in Beijing, does not usually pay much attention to manners. He does not mind when people blast loud music, and he strolls the alleyways near his home in a tank top stained with grease. But when a stranger recently ditched a bicycle in the bushes outside his door, Mr. Liu was irate.
2017-09-02.headline_main: As Bike-Sharing Brings Out Bad Manners, China Asks, What’s Wrong With Us?

2017-09-02.abstract: Confederate statues are not our only monuments to self-delusion.
2017-09-02.snippet: Confederate statues are not our only monuments to self-delusion.
2017-09-02.lead_paragraph: HOTELS generally don’t figure prominently in my imagination, but Yosemite Valley does, and so does the glamorous Ahwahnee Hotel. When my father took me on Yosemite climbing trips in the 1980s, we never stayed at the Ahwahnee — it costs a fortune — but Dad always brought clean dress shirts so that we could hang out in the Ahwahnee’s kitschy Indian Room Bar before we slept illegally under the evergreens.
2017-09-02.headline_main: Goodbye, Yosemite. Hello, What?

2017-09-02.abstract: He talks about his love for miners and factory workers. So far, he hasn’t done much to show it.
2017-09-02.snippet: He talks about his love for miners and factory workers. So far, he hasn’t done much to show it.
2017-09-02.lead_paragraph: Even though Donald Trump is a flamboyant billionaire, many blue-collar voters embraced him as the presidential candidate who would lift them out of their economic rut. “I will bring jobs back and get wages up,” Mr. Trump said last summer, vowing to get tough on trade, Mexico and China.
2017-09-02.headline_main: Is Trump Really Pro-Worker?

2017-09-02.abstract: Salvadoran women are facing an epidemic of violence fueled by impunity and a culture that normalizes machismo.
2017-09-02.snippet: Salvadoran women are facing an epidemic of violence fueled by impunity and a culture that normalizes machismo.
2017-09-02.lead_paragraph: SAN SALVADOR — I don’t want to go back to El Salvador. I felt afraid as a woman there more than in any other country in Latin America. I realized I had entered hostile territory while chatting with the taxi driver who picked me up at the airport, the first Salvadoran man I met. He told me he had a baby, a little darling called J. J., and showed me a photo.
2017-09-02.headline_main: In El Salvador, ‘Girls Are a Problem’

2017-09-02.abstract: Well before most of them will announce they are running, prospective Democratic candidates for president are taking steps to lay the financial foundation for a campaign.
2017-09-02.snippet: Well before most of them will announce they are running, prospective Democratic candidates for president are taking steps to lay the financial foundation for a campaign.
2017-09-02.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Aides to Senator Kamala Harris of California say that her fund-raisers in Martha’s Vineyard and the Hamptons this summer have been all about helping Democrats in 2018. Former Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr.’s allies say his new political group is building an email list so he can communicate directly with his supporters about the future of the party and the country. And Representative Tim Ryan of Ohio says he has been traveling to Iowa and New Hampshire in part because “I like being out around the country.”
2017-09-02.headline_main: Long List of Top Democrats Have 2020, and Money, on Their Minds

2017-09-02.abstract: A 1928 pact brought an end to the right of conquest and changed the way states behave.
2017-09-02.snippet: A 1928 pact brought an end to the right of conquest and changed the way states behave.
2017-09-02.lead_paragraph: If you were to ask historians to name the most foolish treaty ever signed, odds are good that they would name the  Kellogg-Briand Pact of 1928. The pact, which was joined by 63 nations, outlawed war. Ending war is an absurdly ambitious goal. To think it could be done by treaty? Not just absurd but dangerously naïve.
2017-09-02.headline_main: Outlawing War? It Actually Worked

2017-09-02.abstract: A food historian says everyday, forgettable meals are where the real stories are.
2017-09-02.snippet: A food historian says everyday, forgettable meals are where the real stories are.
2017-09-02.lead_paragraph: I am a culinary historian, and scrolling through the endless food on Instagram makes me hungry. No, not for the fresh-baked sourdough rolls nestled so prettily in a linen napkin or that jaunty tumbler of strawberry mousse sporting its shiny green sprigs of mint. They look delicious, but what really makes my mouth water is the thought of all the stories behind them — everything that happened in the kitchen before you picked up your phone and clicked.
2017-09-02.headline_main: Instagram Your Leftovers: History Depends on It

2017-09-02.lead_paragraph: SUNDAY PUZZLE — For about a month, my dog, Jade — known to most as The Extremely Spunky Border terrier, or ESBT — enjoyed an unusual friendship. Border terriers were bred to rid their Scottish ancestors’ households of rodents, and they still “go to ground,” as it is called, but Jade has never shown any particular interest in her genetic lot. She’s a lover, not a fighter, so when the rabbit came knocking, Jade’s reaction was: “Cool! Another four-legged friend to play with!”
2017-09-02.headline_main: United Kingdom

2017-09-03.abstract: The latest Rockford Peaches are another tribute to the All-American Girls Professional Baseball League, which was also re-created on film 25 years ago.
2017-09-03.snippet: The latest Rockford Peaches are another tribute to the All-American Girls Professional Baseball League, which was also re-created on film 25 years ago.
2017-09-03.lead_paragraph: SOUTH ELGIN, Ill. — Strike one. “You swing like a girl!” the pitcher barked, heckling yet another player at the plate. Sonja Bushnick of the Rockford Peaches lifted her wooden bat again. She passed on one ball and fouled off another. On the next pitch she hit a short pop-up that the pitcher caught with ease. He laughed at her.

2017-09-03.abstract: “Pacific Standard Time: LA/LA” with some 70 museum exhibitions, is a must-see in a season of old masters, overdue solos and big surveys.
2017-09-03.snippet: “Pacific Standard Time: LA/LA” with some 70 museum exhibitions, is a must-see in a season of old masters, overdue solos and big surveys.
2017-09-03.lead_paragraph: Size-wise, the biggest deal of the new art season comes right at the start with “Pacific Standard Time: LA/LA,” a roundup of some 70 museum exhibitions in Los Angeles and throughout Southern California devoted to Latin American and Latino art. The chronological arc is wide, from pre-Columbian gold to contemporary performance. So is the ethnic spectrum, with surveys of Afro-Brazilian and Chinese Caribbean art, and work by artists of Japanese descent living in Lima, Peru, and Mexico City.
2017-09-03.headline_main: A West Coast Spotlight on Latino Artists Leads the Fall Art Season

2017-09-03.lead_paragraph: EAST HAMPTON, N.Y. — The Cedar Island Lighthouse, a quaint, cubic structure of notably large granite blocks in Suffolk County’s Cedar Point Park, once appeared a fortress. 2017-09-03.abstract: The food at Brothers Food & Wine, which opened last October in a slim, plain space just above the Bay Street subway station, is richly complex and utterly satisfying.

The two met in Toronto culinary circles, then rose up through boundary-pushing London kitchens — Dandelyan for Mr. White; St. John for Mr. Nicolaou.

2017-09-03.abstract: In Stephen Baxter’s authorized follow-up to H. G. Wells’s science-fiction classic, the Martians return, and this time they know what they’re doing.
2017-09-03.snippet: In Stephen Baxter’s authorized follow-up to H. G. Wells’s science-fiction classic, the Martians return, and this time they know what they’re doing.
2017-09-03.lead_paragraph: It was 120 years ago that H. G. Wells’s “The War of the Worlds,” about a Martian invasion of Earth, appeared as a magazine serial. (In the United States, the story was rolled out in Cosmopolitan.) Nearly 80 years ago, a radio dramatization of the novel caused “a wave of mass hysteria,” according to The New York Times, among some listeners who didn’t know the terrifying scenario was fiction. Now, Stephen Baxter has written a sequel, “The Massacre of Mankind,” authorized by Wells’s estate. (Baxter is the author of dozens of science-fiction books, and, even more pertinently, a vice president of the H.G. Wells Society.) His book was published in Britain earlier this year, where The Guardian said: “It’s Baxter’s best novel in a long time, and this may be because it reads like a genuine labor of love.” Below, Baxter talks about the evolution of Wells’s original story, his own childhood love of science fiction and more.
2017-09-03.headline_main: Tell Us 5 Things About Your Book: A Sequel to ‘The War of the Worlds’

2017-09-04.snippet: Caught between rampant development and NIMBYism.
2017-09-04.lead_paragraph: The waters are receding in Houston, and so, inevitably, is national interest. But Harvey will leave a huge amount of wreckage behind, some of it invisible. In particular, we don’t yet know just how much poison has been released by flooding of chemical plants, waste dumps, and more. But it’s a good bet that more people will eventually die from the toxins Harvey leaves behind than were killed during the storm itself.

2017-09-04.snippet: If unions are going to return to their old strength, they need rules tailored to modern workplaces.
2017-09-04.lead_paragraph: Labor Day was born in the late 19th century, during a time of raw fear about the path of economic development. Opportunities for decent, middle-class livelihoods seemed to be shrinking, and the “laboring classes” confronted a grim future of what many called wage slavery. Conservatives held most of the seats of power, but reform-minded politicians, activists and policy mavens were thinking big about labor’s rights and wrongs.
2017-09-04.headline_main: A New Type of Labor Law for a New Type of Worker

2017-09-04.abstract: The art world is obsessed with unpretty pictures. But why?
2017-09-04.snippet: The art world is obsessed with unpretty pictures. But why?
2017-09-04.lead_paragraph: Lost in the fun house of Laura Owens’s unstoppably inventive show at the gallery Sadie Coles HQ in London last year, I spent a whole afternoon eyeballing a painting of Garfield. The L.A.-based Owens transforms elements that could be too swiftly called ‘‘zany’’ or ‘‘lurid’’ — rainbow sprinkles as a psychedelic garland on wallpaper; stoned, Crayola-like squiggles; swirls of oil paint thick as cake frosting — into something ravishing. In a 2013 interview, the artist said she had no intention of making ‘‘good’’ art, art that fulfills some fussy criteria of taste or beauty; the opposite impulse, she suggested, is always more fruitful.
2017-09-04.headline_main: The Beauty of Ugly Painting

2017-09-04.snippet: With about $650 billion in U.S.-China trade on the line, Washington must tread carefully if it wants to pressure Beijing to take a tougher line on Pyongyang.
2017-09-04.lead_paragraph: SHANGHAI — President Trump said on Sunday that the United States could consider stopping all trade with countries doing business in North Korea, in a move that could spell economic catastrophe for the pugnacious country.
2017-09-04.headline_main: Trump Can’t Stop Trade With North Korea. But He Does Have Options.

2017-09-04.abstract: Some fellow laureates have confronted the de facto leader of Myanmar over its treatment of the Rohingya, but a Nobel Prize has never been rescinded.
2017-09-04.snippet: Some fellow laureates have confronted the de facto leader of Myanmar over its treatment of the Rohingya, but a Nobel Prize has never been rescinded.
2017-09-04.lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — Daw Aung San Suu Kyi, the de facto leader of Myanmar and a Nobel Peace Prize laureate who once embodied her country’s fight for democracy, came under increased pressure on Monday to denounce a military operation that has caused thousands of Muslim refugees to flee across the border to Bangladesh.
2017-09-04.headline_main: Why Aung San Suu Kyi’s Nobel Peace Prize Won’t Be Revoked

2017-09-04.abstract: The museum is searching for a director. Maybe it’s time for a woman to assume control.
2017-09-04.snippet: The museum is searching for a director. Maybe it’s time for a woman to assume control.
2017-09-04.lead_paragraph: There are many exciting museum shows to see across the country in coming months. But of particular interest to me will be the one unfolding in real time at the Metropolitan Museum of Art as this august institution tries to right itself after several years of staff unrest, financial mismanagement and overreach. A lot has happened since Thomas P. Campbell, its director of eight years, resigned under pressure in late February, but it’s not over. The most obvious questions are: Who will be the next director, and when will he — or, better yet, she — be appointed?
2017-09-04.headline_main: The Fall’s Most Fascinating Art Show? The Met Trying to Fix Itself

2017-09-04.abstract: Does it even matter that so many questions were left unanswered?
2017-09-04.snippet: Does it even matter that so many questions were left unanswered?
2017-09-04.lead_paragraph: In May of 1990, ABC aired the “Twin Peaks” Season 1 finale, and frustrated viewers who’d expected the show’s creators David Lynch and Mark Frost to resolve the “Who killed Laura Palmer?” mystery. In June of 1991, “Twin Peaks” Season 2 also ended with more questions than answers, and stuck fans with a cruel twist, revealing that heroic FBI Agent Dale Cooper had been replaced by an evil twin. So if you were confounded by the way the third (and perhaps last-ever) “Twin Peaks” season wrapped up last night ... well, call it tradition. Whether by circumstance or intent, this has always been a TV drama that eschews tidy resolutions.
2017-09-04.headline_main: ‘Twin Peaks’ Season 3 Finale: The Curtain Call

2017-09-04.abstract: In almost every mammal species, an infant’s cry has a primal impact on nearby adults. Scientists are beginning to figure out why.
2017-09-04.snippet: In almost every mammal species, an infant’s cry has a primal impact on nearby adults. Scientists are beginning to figure out why.
2017-09-04.lead_paragraph: A normal human baby, according to psychologists, will cry about two hours over the course of a day.
2017-09-04.headline_main: A Baby Wails, and the Adult World Comes Running

2017-09-04.abstract: In 2013, Sal Albanese got 0.9 percent of the Democratic mayoral primary vote, finishing eighth out of nine. This year, the worst he can do is second.
2017-09-04.snippet: In 2013, Sal Albanese got 0.9 percent of the Democratic mayoral primary vote, finishing eighth out of nine. This year, the worst he can do is second.
2017-09-04.lead_paragraph: The candidate sat in a dark suit and yellow monogrammed tie on an R train headed to Crown Heights, Brooklyn, to campaign with an old friend. Little gave away that the man was nearly at the end of another quixotic campaign to become mayor of New York, except for a small navy button with his first name: Sal.
2017-09-04.headline_main: Twice Beaten, Thrice Shy? Not for Sal Albanese, Mayoral Hopeful. Again.

2017-09-04.abstract: Rushdie’s 13th novel is exhausting, but it’s a treat when focused on a villain who resembles Donald Trump.
2017-09-04.snippet: Rushdie’s 13th novel is exhausting, but it’s a treat when focused on a villain who resembles Donald Trump.
2017-09-04.lead_paragraph: When Salman Rushdie began work on his second novel, “Midnight’s Children” (1981), the one that would make his name, he realized, he has written, that he could not write his book “in cool Forsterian English. India was not cool. It was hot. It was hot and overcrowded and vulgar and loud and it needed a language to match that,” and he would try to find that language.
2017-09-04.headline_main: Salman Rushdie’s Prose Joins the Circus in ‘The Golden House’

2017-09-04.abstract: With Steely Dan, he produced some of the most artistically and commercially potent music of the 1970s and early ’80s.
2017-09-04.snippet: With Steely Dan, he produced some of the most artistically and commercially potent music of the 1970s and early ’80s.
2017-09-04.lead_paragraph: When you think of Steely Dan, you probably hear Donald Fagen’s brackish snarl in the front of your mind. But Walter Becker, the group’s other half, played an equal role in defining its sound and direction. Mr. Becker, who died on Sunday at 67, founded Steely Dan — which was more of a protean studio project than a band with any set personnel — with Mr. Fagen, his perennial musical partner, in 1972. They sculpted a literary, restlessly inventive brand of jazz-rock, producing some of the most artistically and commercially potent music of that era. The group returned to touring in the 1990s, and released two warmly received albums in the new millennium. Here are 13 essential tracks that showcase Mr. Becker’s talents, including two from his low-profile solo career.
2017-09-04.headline_main: Listen to 13 Essential Walter Becker Songs

2017-09-04.abstract: A former high school teacher, Ms. Vreeland was best known for her novel “Girl in Hyacinth Blue,” which traces the history of a fictional painting.
2017-09-04.snippet: A former high school teacher, Ms. Vreeland was best known for her novel “Girl in Hyacinth Blue,” which traces the history of a fictional painting.

2017-09-04.abstract: The Billboard album chart this week again showed the power of streaming, as Lil Uzi Vert’s “Luv Is Rage 2” and XXXTentacion’s “17” took the top two spots.
2017-09-04.snippet: The Billboard album chart this week again showed the power of streaming, as Lil Uzi Vert’s “Luv Is Rage 2” and XXXTentacion’s “17” took the top two spots.

2017-09-04.lead_paragraph: TELLURIDE, Colo. — Spending time at a film festival is like living inside an accordion. Time expands and contracts — months are compressed into a few hours of screen time, and a day of screenings lasts a week — and you can’t always extract the music from the noise. The Telluride Film Festival, which spans each Labor Day weekend in this high-altitude former mining town, is an old-time squeeze box wired up to a Dolby sound system.

2017-09-04.lead_paragraph: Washington — For over a decade, Allison and Katie Crutchfield have been making music together, on terms of their own making. As teenagers, the twin sisters formed the cheery, poppy punk outfit the Ackleys, and later the more controlled and lyrically ambitious P.S. Eliot. Beginning around five years ago, they began working on their own projects — the confessional Waxahatchee for Katie, the swaggering, now-defunct Swearin’ for Allison — which elevated them from D.I.Y. stalwarts to indie-rock flagbearers.

2017-09-04.lead_paragraph: Over the past decade, the DNA laboratory in the office of New York City’s chief medical examiner emerged as a pioneer in analyzing the most complicated evidence from crime scenes. It developed two techniques, which went beyond standard practice at the F.B.I. and other public labs, for making identifications from DNA samples that were tiny or that contained a mix of more than one person’s genetic material.

But pondering the journey of these two small space explorers reminds us of just how far humanity has traveled in just a few decades.

2017-09-05.abstract: Before becoming a novelist, I spent six years at war. Years later, I came to America and finally met my old enemies.
2017-09-05.snippet: Before becoming a novelist, I spent six years at war. Years later, I came to America and finally met my old enemies.
2017-09-05.lead_paragraph: HANOI, Vietnam — I first visited the United States in the summer of 1998, when I was invited to attend a literary conference in Montana with four other Vietnamese writers. We flew from Hanoi to Taiwan to Los Angeles. As we crossed the Pacific Ocean, passing through many time zones, I buried myself in sleep and woke up only when the plane hit the tarmac. At passport control, we found ourselves in a huge hall, and I was abruptly taken aback: There were Americans all around us, lots of them! I will never forget that strange feeling. It was bizarre, unbelievable, surreal, that I, a veteran of the Vietnamese People’s Army, was in the United States, surrounded by Americans.
2017-09-05.headline_main: The First Time I Met Americans

2017-09-05.abstract: For decades, we talked about Nazis mostly in analogies, jokes and caricatures. Now we’re debating whether it’s a fair word for describing a good number of our neighbors.
2017-09-05.snippet: For decades, we talked about Nazis mostly in analogies, jokes and caricatures. Now we’re debating whether it’s a fair word for describing a good number of our neighbors.
2017-09-05.lead_paragraph: One morning in mid-August, Americans woke up in what felt, to some, like an altered country. The week’s most notable political event had begun with hundreds of Americans carrying torches while chanting “Sieg heil” and “Jews will not replace us.” White supremacist radicals like these had been active and energized throughout the presidential campaign, but much of their energy had been restricted to the internet. The rally in Charlottesville was markedly different. It confronted America with an unlikely question: Was it possible the nation was seeing a burgeoning political faction of ... actual Nazis? People we should actually call Nazis?
2017-09-05.headline_main: Americans Are Confronting an Alarming Question: Are Many of Our Fellow Citizens ‘Nazis’?

2017-09-05.lead_paragraph: Toss a dart at a map of Detroit, and the bull’s-eye, more or less, would be a tiny city called Highland Park. Only three square miles, Highland Park is surrounded by Detroit on nearly all sides, but it remains its own sovereign municipality thanks largely to Henry Ford, who started building Model Ts there in 1910. Ford didn’t care for the idea of paying Detroit taxes, so he pressured Highland Park to resist annexation by the larger city. By the end of the decade, his Albert Kahn-designed factory had revolutionized mass production. Five years later, Walter Chrysler started his own car company a few blocks away.
2017-09-05.headline_main: Michigan Gambled on Charter Schools. Its Children Lost.

2017-09-05.lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — When David Hockney began his career, figurative painting was considered old hat and even retrogressive. The assumption, in advanced circles, was that abstraction was wholly superior, raising large, lofty questions about the essence of painting instead of getting bogged down in the picayune details of postwar life. What possible wisdom could be gleaned from a painting that depicts a palm tree, for instance, or the glistening turquoise of a backyard swimming pool?

2017-09-05.snippet: The latest from Ravi DeRossi, dim-sum-style Italian in the West Village, and other restaurant news.
2017-09-05.lead_paragraph: THE DESSERT BAR AT PATISSERIE CHANSON When the pastry chef Rory Macdonald opened his bakery and cafe last spring, he planned to develop the lower level of the spacious store as a tasting room for desserts and cocktails. It took longer than expected — what doesn’t in the restaurant world? Finally, it’s ready, and just in time for the fall season. The underground space was discovered during the construction of the pastry shop upstairs, and it turns out that it was once a speakeasy, a bit of history that seems to be turning up often these days. It was also a gambling school, and Chanson’s cocktail menu nods to that with drinks like Poker Alice, named for a gambler and mixed with assorted liqueurs. There’s a 16-seat dessert bar, as well as booths and tables, and playing-card motifs on the walls. The six-course dessert tasting, which includes some more savory items, like olive oil gelato with sea salt and eucalyptus to clear the palate, is $68, by reservation for people of drinking age. (Opens Thursday): 20 West 23rd Street, lower level, 929-423-8880, patisseriechanson.com.
2017-09-05.headline_main: Patisserie Chanson’s Dessert Bar Opens in Flatiron District

2017-09-05.lead_paragraph: Trump’s decision to kill DACA — never mind the attempt to obscure things with that meaningless delay — is, first and foremost, a moral obscenity: throwing out 800,000 young people who are Americans in every way that matters, who have done nothing wrong, basically for racial reasons. But it’s also worth noting that Jeff Sessions just tried to sell it with junk economics, claiming that the Dreamers are taking American jobs. No, they aren’t, even if we leave aside the question of who’s an American. DACA is very much a boon to the rest of the U.S. population, and killing it will make everyone worse off.
2017-09-05.headline_main: The Very Bad Economics of Killing DACA

2017-09-05.abstract: A documentary about Monticchiello in Italy, where each year the residents put on a play about their most urgent concerns.
2017-09-05.snippet: A documentary about Monticchiello in Italy, where each year the residents put on a play about their most urgent concerns.
2017-09-05.lead_paragraph: Some tell their stories in kitchens, warming hands and souls over coffee; others write confessions. For decades, the residents of the tiny Tuscan town of Monticchiello have turned their lives into theater. Each year, they gather to discuss art and their world until they land on a topic that reflects their most recent, urgent concerns. Word by word, they push and pull, challenging one another as they shape a production. All the world’s a stage, but in Monticchiello that truism is movingly real, especially because these days its aging resident-players have more exits than entrances.
2017-09-05.headline_main: Review: In ‘Spettacolo,’ a Tuscan Town Where All the World’s a Stage

2017-09-05.abstract: A president who doesn’t believe in the value of America’s Dreamers is not one I can continue to support.

2017-09-05.lead_paragraph: Right now in the United States there are some 800,000 law-abiding young people without proper immigration papers who nevertheless proudly call America home. Today President Trump sent them a clear message: They are not welcome here. With its decision to terminate the Deferred Action for Childhood Arrivals program, which has protected these “Dreamers” since 2012, the administration claims that it is merely insisting that Congress take responsibility for the program. That is a dodge, and a cowardly one. This cruel new policy is also a direct contradiction of the promise that President Trump made to the Hispanic community only months ago.

He traveled a path from working as an unskilled laborer at a locomotive assembly plant in Rostov-on-Don, a large industrial city in southern Russia, to becoming the head of military transportations for the strategic North Caucasian Railroad.

2017-09-05.abstract: Much of life consists of musing moments when we look at something so beautiful or surprising that we wonder, briefly, who we are. This is the feeling the poet gave his readers.
2017-09-05.snippet: Much of life consists of musing moments when we look at something so beautiful or surprising that we wonder, briefly, who we are. This is the feeling the poet gave his readers.
2017-09-05.lead_paragraph: In 1965, when he was nearly 40 and his unorthodox talent was in full bloom, John Ashbery joined his friend Kenneth Koch for a mutual interview commissioned by a small press in Arizona. After a brief tongue-in-cheek discussion of how poems communicate, or don’t, Koch remarked that some uncertainties “enable the reader to escape from his ordinary consciousness of himself,” and suggested that it could be “very enjoyable” to feel like “a person you know nothing about.”
2017-09-05.headline_main: John Ashbery, the Gift of Quiet Moments

2017-09-05.lead_paragraph: AUSTIN, Tex. — As I sat in my office complaining about the rain we were having here more than a week ago, I stumbled across a Facebook page run by the Rockport Volunteer Fire Department and the words hit me like a bus. “Fellow First Responders who are willing to go in and help we need certified, capable able-bodied people to come help,” it read. As my wife read the post over my shoulder, she put her hand on me and said, “Be safe down there sweetheart.” She knew I was going.

2017-09-05.snippet: The architect Andrea Tognon lives and works on a property he got for free, which was once a neglected industrial complex.
2017-09-05.lead_paragraph: THE NORTHERN MILAN district of Bicocca is not an obvious inspiration for an architect’s fantasies. Semi-industrial (but not in that noble wrought-iron way), perpetually bedraggled and largely devoid of historical significance, Bicocca is just 20 minutes from fashion’s golden triangle of Via Monte Napoleone, Via della Spiga and Via Sant’Andrea, but it’s as defiantly dour and dazzle-free as that area is refined and lacquered. The district’s signature feature is Borgo Pirelli, an early 20th-century village of red-roofed, low-slung apartment clusters, now used as public housing, built to keep the Pirelli tire factory workers tethered to the nearby assembly line. In 2004, the company turned one of its spaces into a cavernous gallery, HangarBicocca, featuring site-specific, 82-ton Anselm Kiefer installations, but there’s been no Bilbao effect, no open tap of artists streaming in searching for loft space. Change comes slowly in Italy, and the Milanese have never seen much charm in grittiness.
2017-09-05.headline_main: In a Desolate Corner of Milan, an Unexpected Home
